title: Joan Benoit
text: Short bio here. Nascetur ridiculus mus mauris vitae ultricies. Ultrices vitae auctor eu augue ut lectus. Vulputate eu scelerisque felis.

english: Renée Watson: Okay, so I’m here with Tupili Lea [E.] Arellano. Thank you so much for opening your home and time to this work together; it is such a gift and honor. Can you please tell me your name and who you are?

Joan Benoit: My name is Tupili Lea Espinosa Arellano, and I am a seventy-year-old indigenous elder. My tribal families are Mayo and Meshika [phonetic] and Rarámuri, and one of my tía [aunt] says we have Apache, and right now, that’s what I’m saying that,—the tribal family that I carry in my DNA [deoxyribonucleic acid], and what else? I’m an elder, and I’ve been a social justice activist from a very early age. And the first time I went to the streets was 1968 to fight against the Vietnam War that we were waging, and I was very active since then. And that was in Silver City, New Mexico, a very small, conservative town, but there were people that just said, “You’re coming with us,” so. And I was already calling out in my family the things that were not okay, which is a form of activism.
Renée: Thank you, and when and where were you born?

Renée Watson: Okay, so I’m here with Tupili Lea [E.] Arellano. Thank you so much for opening your home and time to this work together; it is such a gift and honor. Can you please tell me your name and who you are?

Renée Watson: Okay, so I’m here with Tupili Lea [E.] Arellano. Thank you so much for opening your home and time to this work together; it is such a gift and honor. Can you please tell me your name and who you are?
spanish: Renée Watson: Bueno, estoy aquí con Tupili Lea [E.] Arellano. Muchas gracias por abrir tu hogar y tu tiempo para trabajar juntos; es un verdadero regalo y un honor. ¿Podrías decirme tu nombre y quién eres?

Joan Benoit: Mi nombre es Tupili Lea Espinosa Arellano, y soy una anciana indígena de setenta años. Mis familias tribales son Mayo y Meshika [fonético] y Rarámuri, y una de mis tías dice que tenemos Apache, y eso es lo que estoy diciendo ahora, la familia tribal que llevo en mi ADN [ácido desoxirribonucleico], ¿y qué más? Soy una anciana y he sido activista por la justicia social desde muy joven. La primera vez que salí a las calles fue en 1968 para luchar contra la Guerra de Vietnam que estábamos librando, y he sido muy activa desde entonces. Y eso fue en Silver City, Nuevo México, un pueblo muy pequeño y conservador, pero había gente que simplemente decía: 'Vienes con nosotros', así que. Y ya estaba señalando en mi familia las cosas que no estaban bien, lo cual es una forma de activismo.
Renée: Thank you, and when and where were you born?

Renée Watson: Okay, so I’m here with Tupili Lea [E.] Arellano. Thank you so much for opening your home and time to this work together; it is such a gift and honor. Can you please tell me your name and who you are?

Renée Watson: Okay, so I’m here with Tupili Lea [E.] Arellano. Thank you so much for opening your home and time to this work together; it is such a gift and honor. Can you please tell me your name and who you are?
